sn54.7:4.2: Now, at that time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was sitting not far from the Buddha in the meditation posture, with his body erect, and mindfulness established right there.
sn54.7:5.1: “Mendicants, do you see any motion or trembling in that mendicant’s body?”
sn54.7:5.2: “Sir, whenever we see that mendicant meditating—whether in the middle of the Sangha or alone in private—we never see any motion or trembling in his body.”
sn54.7:6.1: “Mendicants, when a samādhi has been developed and cultivated there’s no motion or trembling of the body or mind. That mendicant gets such samādhi when he wants, without trouble or difficulty.
sn54.7:7.1: When samādhi due to mindfulness of breathing has been developed and cultivated there’s no motion or trembling of the body or mind.
sn54.7:7.2: And how is samādhi due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated in such a way?
sn54.7:8.1: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down in the meditation posture, with their body erect, and establishes their mindfulness right there.
sn54.7:8.2: Ever mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out. …
sn54.7:8.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
sn54.7:8.4: That’s how samādhi due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated so that there’s no motion or trembling of the body or mind.”
